ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Syllabus accurately conveys what we learned

This course provides insights into alternative approaches to democracy which engage the American public to a greater degree. The course primarily centers around reading texts prior to class, submitting thoughts on the readings ahead of time, and then discussing the topic of the week in the seminar. The course itself develops what forms of government would be feasible in the United States and invites the students to conceptualize beyond what has previously been done at the large scale in the United States. Furthermore, with the Discussion Leader component of the class, you get to learn how to guide a small group and draw out participation from your peers as you're basically in charge of the class.
I learned skills of debating and using insightful information from my classmates for open minded discussions.
I gained an understanding of the theory undergirding participatory democracy, some real-world applications of it, and some hypothetical proposals of it.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The course is structured quite well to where you first understand the current "Crisis of Democracy" and get a philosophical overview of the idea of participatory democracy. It then moves into the theories in practice with studies conducted in a variety of contexts and geographic regions (such as labor unions in Europe and schools in South America). That said, at times, the reading can get heavy but it is essential to being able to meaningfully contribute to class discussion, so perhaps the readings could be condensed into smaller segments?
Professor was an amazing discussion leader and had extremely interesting topics.

The seminar discussions sometimes didn't directly address the actual readings as much as I would like. People often just gave their general impressions and speculations, which I typically don't find as valuable. Overall, however, I enjoyed the course, and I got a lot out of the readings.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Great class. Low-stakes way to have meaningful conversations about democracy and what it might look like going forward.
Professor Fairdosi is a kind and fun professor. Discussions are interesting. Readings aren't too long. It's a good course, I recommend.

Yes, Professor Fairdosi is a wonderful professor and the class genuinely changed my outlook on what I thought was the best way to govern, both at the large and small scales. It also highlighted the importance of engaging politically with those in your immediate circles of influence rather than focusing on doing so at a larger level. I would highly recommend this course, especially to anyone interested in alternative forms of government and political philosophy.

I would recommend this course to any student interested in participatory democracy or structural changes to democracy more generally. Going in, I was skeptical of participatory democracy, and I left more of a fan of it and with a better idea of what it looks like in practice.
